case_name: State of Rajasthan v. Ram Saran

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 453 of 1962 filed by State of Rajasthan.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 453 of 1962. Appeal from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated November 18, 1960 of Rajasthan High Court in D.B. Civil Writ No. 264 of 1959.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated November 18, 1960, of the Rajasthan High Court in D. B. Civil Writ No. 264 of 1959.

facts.text: Certificate of fitness granted by High Court of Rajasthan under Art. 133(1)(c) of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: this appeal which has been filed pursuant to a certificate of fitness granted by the High Court of Rajasthan under Art. 133  1   c  of the companystitution

facts.text: Ram Saran appointed as Constable in 1947 in Ajmer district police force.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent, Ram Saran, was appointed a Constable in 1947 in the Ajmer district police force.

facts.text: Ram Saran promoted to Head Constable two years after 1947 and confirmed in that post.

anchor.surface_text: Two years thereafter he was promoted to the rank of Head Constable and was companyfirmed in that post.

facts.text: Ram Saran appointed to officiate as Sub-Inspector on June 29, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: On June 29, 1956 he was appointed to officiate as a SubInspector.

facts.text: States Reorganisation Act XXXVII of 1956 enacted, operative from November 1, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: At that stage the states Reorganisation Act  XXXVII of 1956 , hereinafter referred to as the Act, was enacted -which became operative from November 1, 1956,

facts.text: Ajmer merged in Rajasthan by States Reorganisation Act.

anchor.surface_text: referred to in the Act as the appointed date,, and by virtue of its provisions the former State, of Ajmer was merged in the State of Rajasthan

facts.text: Ram Saran absorbed in Police Service of Rajasthan State on November 1, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: and under its terms again the respondent was absorbed in the Police Service of the Rajasthan State.

facts.text: Formal order appointing Ram Saran as officiating Sub-Inspector in Rajasthan State police force dated November 1, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: To give effect to this provision a formal order appointing the respondent as an officiating Sub-Inspector in the Rajasthan State police force was also passed dated the same day.

facts.text: Deputy Inspector General of Police, Ajmer Range ordered reversion of Ram Saran to substantive post of Head Constable on April 6, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: Subsequent thereto, on April 6, 1957 the Deputy Inspector General of Police, Ajmer Range ordered the reversion of the respondent to his substantive post of Head Constable in the District Police Force.

facts.text: Ram Saran filed petition under Art. 226 on July 22, 1959 to quash reversion order dated April 6, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: When he did number succeed in his efforts, he filed, on July 22, 1959, a petition under Art. 226 of the companystitution for quashing the order of reversion dated April 6, 1957,

facts.text: Rajasthan High Court allowed the writ petition principally on ground of violation of s.115 of States Reorganisation Act.

anchor.surface_text: and the learned judges of the High Court allowed it principally on the ground that this order of reversion was in violation of the provisions of s. 115 of the Act.

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment delivered on April 10, 1963 by AYYANGAR J.

anchor.surface_text: 1963. April 10. The judgment of the Court was delivered by AYYANGAR.J.-

facts.text: Standing Order 46 issued by Inspector General of Police, Ajmer dated October 20, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: The Standing Order relied on is one numbered 46 issued by the Inspector General of Police, Ajmer and is dated October 20, 1949.

facts.text: Letter from Deputy Secretary, GOI Ministry of Home Affairs to Chief Secretary Rajasthan dated March 27, 1957 on protection of service conditions.

anchor.surface_text: The direction was claimed to be companytained in a letter from the Deputy secretary to the Government of India Ministry of Home Affairs to the Chief Secretary to the Government of Rajasthan, Jaipur dated March 27, 1957

facts.text: Ram Saran dissatisfied with reversion order claiming it was not in normal course of posting and amounted to supersession by juniors.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent was dissatisfied with this order and his companyplaint was that it was number one passed in the numbermal companyrse of posting since there were, on that date, officiating Sub-Inspectors in the State police force who were junior to him

facts.text: Supreme Court held reversion not by way of punishment under Art. 311.

anchor.surface_text: it was number suggested that the order of reversion was one by way of punishment companystituting a reduction in rank so as to attract Art. 311 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed appeal, set aside High Court order, dismissed writ petition.

anchor.surface_text: The result is that the appeal is allowed and the order of the High Court set aside and the Writs Petition of the respondent dismissed.

facts.text: Respondent claimed violation of Art. 14 due to regional seniority lists for promotions and reversions.

anchor.surface_text: that for the purpose of promotions and for determining reversions the seniority in the police force was number companyputed on the basis of a list of seniority prepared for the entire State of Rajasthan but that the same was done on a regional basis

facts.text: Supreme Court noted Art. 14 claim too vague, not decided on merits, liberty to file fresh petition.

anchor.surface_text: Having- companysidered the suggestion carefully we have arrived at the companyclusion that on the pleadings, as they stand, this question companyld number be determined satisfactorily.

issues.text: Whether the computation of seniority in the police force on a regional basis for promotions and reversions, instead of on a state-wide basis, violates Article 14 of the Constitution?

anchor.surface_text: it was not suggested that the order of reversion was one by way of punishment constituting a reduction in rank so as to attract Art. 311 of the Constitution. The grievances of the respondent as formulated before us were threefold  1  that for the purpose of promotions and for determining reversions the seniority in the police force was number companyputed on the basis of a list of seniority prepared for the entire State of Rajasthan but that the same was done on a regional basis

issues.text: Whether the reversion violated Standing Order 46 and whether Standing Order 46 constitutes a statutory condition of service protected under section 115(7) of the States Reorganisation Act?

anchor.surface_text: The Standing Order relied on is one numbered 46 issued by the Inspector General of Police, Ajmer and is dated October 20, 1949. The relevant portion of it relied on is the paragraph numbered 4  b  which reads An officer who has secured officiating pro- motion on the basis of his place on the approved list should numbermally be companyidered for promotion earlier provided that he main- tains an appropriate standard.

issues.text: Whether the reversion from officiating Sub-Inspector to substantive Head Constable constitutes an alteration in conditions of service to the disadvantage of the respondent requiring previous approval of the Central Government under the proviso to section 115(7) of the States Reorganisation Act?

anchor.surface_text: It was further contended by the respondent that the reversion from the officiating post of Sub-Inspector to the substantive one of Head Constable was an alteration in the conditions of his service which the State Government was number companypetent to effect without the sanction of the Central Government under s.115(7) of the Act

issues.text: Whether the Central Government direction under section 117 of the States Reorganisation Act rendered the right to retain the officiating post without reversion a protected condition of service?

anchor.surface_text: The direction was claimed to be contained in a letter from the Deputy secretary to the Government of India Ministry of Home Affairs to the Chief Secretary to the Government of Rajasthan, Jaipur dated March 27, 1957

issues.text: Whether holding an officiating post is a condition of service such that reversion to substantive post without Central Government approval violates the proviso to section 115(7) of the States Reorganisation Act?

anchor.surface_text: What is really crucial for the determination of this appeal is the proviso to sub-s.  7  by which there was a guarantee that the companyditions of service applicable before the appointed day would number be varied to the disadvantage of persons in the position of the respondent except with the previous approval of the-Central Government. The question arising under this proviso would be whether it is any companydition of service applicable to the holder of an officiating post that he shall number be reverted to his substantive post.

arguments.court_reasoning: letter protects only officiating pay for 3 years, not the post itself; s.116(2) saves state power to affect continuance

arguments.claim: Standing Orders of Police Force guarantee no reversion except in strict order of seniority and constitute protected condition under s.115(7)

court_response_anchor.surface_text: iolation of s. 115  7  of the Act. We companysider it would be companyvenient to deal with these in the reverse order, and take up first the interpret

arguments.court_reasoning: Standing Order 46 issued by IGP lacks statutory basis for conditions of service; Police Act s.12 concerns organisation not conditions, s.2 empowers State Government only

arguments.claim: Standing Order 46 deals only with order of consideration for confirmation, not reversion

anchor.surface_text: It is clear from this provision that it deals not with the order in which holders of officiating posts may be reverted but with that in which they could be considered for confirmation

arguments.claim: Standing Orders have no legal efficacy as condition of service unless issued under statutory power

anchor.surface_text: This would depend upon the Standing Orders having been issued by a competent authority under the provisions of a statute which empowered that authority to prescribe conditions of service. For undoubtedly if it were not so it would be merely an administrative instruction

arguments.claim: Inspector General lacks power under Police Act s.12 to frame conditions of service

anchor.surface_text: Section 12 of the Police Act reads, to quote only the material words The Inspector-General of Police may, from time to time, subject to the approval of the State Government, frame such orders and rules as he shall deem expedient relative to the Organisation

arguments.claim: Police Act s.2 vests power to determine conditions of service in State Government, not IGP

anchor.surface_text: Subject to the provisions of this Act-the pay and all other conditions of service of members of the subordinate ranks of any police force shall be such as may be determined by the State Government.

arguments.claim: power to make rules cannot be delegated without express statutory provision

anchor.surface_text: A feeble argument was attempted to suggest that the State Government might have delegated their power to the Inspector General, but nothing is better settled than that a power to make rules could not be delegated without express statutory provision therefore.

arguments.claim: s.116(2) permits competent authority to pass orders affecting continuance in post after appointed day

anchor.surface_text: 116. (1). Every person who immediately before the appointed day is holding or discharging the duties of any post or office in connection with the affairs . of an existing State in any area shall be deemed as from that day to have been duly appointed to such post or office

arguments.claim: right to hold officiating post terminable at any time; reversion not breach of conditions of service

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner before us was appointed to a higher post on an officiating basis He had no right to continue in that post and under the general law the implied term of such appointment was that it was terminable at any time on reasonable notice by Government

arguments.court_reasoning: following Parshotam Lal Dhingra v. Union of India

arguments.claim: s.115(7) proviso does not protect against reversion from officiating post

anchor.surface_text: What is really crucial for the determination of this appeal is the proviso to sub-s.  7  by which there was a guarantee that the conditions of service applicable before the appointed day would not be varied to the disadvantage of persons in the position of the respondent except with the previous approval of the-Central Government.

holdings.text: Standing Order 46 issued by the Inspector General of Police does not constitute a condition of service protected under section 115(7) of the States Reorganisation Act and was not violated by the reversion order.

anchor.surface_text: We therefore consider, with great respect to the learned judges of the High Court, that they were in error in treating Standing Order 46 as a condition of service which was violated by the order of reversion impugned by the respondent in his Writ Petition. Standing Order 46 being put aside,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Standing Orders lack statutory basis under Police Act s.12 (organisation only) and s.2 (State Government power); no delegation possible without express provision; merely administrative instructions.

holdings.text: Reversion from officiating Sub-Inspector to substantive Head Constable does not constitute a variation to the disadvantage of conditions of service under proviso to s.115(7) of States Reorganisation Act requiring Central Government approval.

anchor.surface_text: It therefore appears to us that there is no basis for argument that mere reversion to a substantive post is a breach of the conditions of service. That is why we said that the proviso to sub-s. 7 of s. 115 on which stress is laid by the High Court really affords no assistance to the respondent.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No legal right to continue in officiating post; implied term terminable at any time; follows Parshotam Lal Dhingra v. Union of India.

holdings.text: Holding an officiating post is not a condition of service protected by proviso to s.115(7); reversion to substantive post permitted without Central Government approval.

anchor.surface_text: What is really crucial for the determination of this appeal is the proviso to sub-s. 7 by which there was a guarantee that the conditions of service applicable before the appointed day would not be varied to the disadvantage of persons in the position of the respondent except with the previous approval of the-Central Government.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Officiating holder has no right against reversion; s.116(2) expressly saves power of competent authority to affect continuance in post.

holdings.text: Central Government letter dated March 27, 1957 under s.117 does not protect continuance in officiating post; protects only pay, not post itself.

anchor.surface_text: The direction was claimed to be contained in a letter from the Deputy secretary to the Government of India Ministry of Home Affairs to the Chief Secretary to the Government of Rajasthan, Jaipur dated March 27, 1957 and headed protection of service conditions to be afforded to state service personnel.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Letter addresses pay protection for 3 years officiation; s.116(2) preserves state power over posts; direction does not extend to barring reversion.

holdings.text: Reversion order is not by way of punishment attracting Art.311; no reduction in rank under Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: Before proceeding to consider these provisions it would be convenient to put aside one matter and that is that it was not suggested that the order of reversion was one by way of punishment constituting a reduction in rank so as to attract Art. 311 of the Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Not contested by parties; reversion from officiating post not punitive.

holdings.text: Art.14 claim regarding regional seniority lists cannot be determined on existing vague pleadings; liberty to file fresh petition.

anchor.surface_text: Having- considered the suggestion carefully we have arrived at the conclusion that on the pleadings, as they stand, this question could not be determined satisfactorily.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Pleadings lack details; no evidence led; remittal would require new petition effectively.

precedents.case_name: Parshotam Lal Dhingra v. Union of India
precedents.cited_proposition: an officer appointed to officiate in a higher post has no legal right to continue in that post and reversion to substantive post does not amount to reduction in rank by way of punishment
precedents.cited_holding: The petitioner before us was appointed to a higher post on an officiating basis He had numberright to companytinue in that post and under the general law the implied term of such appointment was that it was terminable at any time on reasonable numberice by Government and therefore his reduction did number operate as a forfeiture of any right and cannot be described as reduction in rank by way of punishment.

anchor.surface_text: We therefore consider, with great respect to the learned judges of the High Court, that they were in error in treating Standing Order 46 as a condition of service which was violated by the order of reversion impugned by the respondent in his Writ Petition. Standing Order 46 being put aside,

The result is that the appeal is allowed and the order of the High Court set aside and the Writs Petition of the respondent dismissed. We have to add that this would be without prejudice to his right to file a fresh petition in regard

anchor.surface_text: It therefore appears to us that there is no basis for argument that mere reversion to a substantive post is a breach of the conditions of service. That is why we said that the proviso to sub-s. 7 of s. 115 on which stress is laid by the High Court really affords no assistance to the respondent.

The result is that the appeal is allowed and the order of the High Court set aside and the Writs Petition of the respondent dismissed. We have to add that this would be without prejudice to his right to file a fresh petition in regard

edges.explanation: The holding directly addresses the issue of whether reversion from an officiating post without Central Government approval violates the proviso to s.115(7), as their descriptions and character spans overlap explicitly.

anchor.surface_text: What is really crucial for the determination of this appeal is the proviso to sub-s. 7 by which there was a guarantee that the conditions of service applicable before the appointed day would not be varied to the disadvantage of persons in the position of the respondent except with the previous approval of the-Central Government.

The result is that the appeal is allowed and the order of the High Court set aside and the Writs Petition of the respondent dismissed. We have to add that this would be without prejudice to his right to file a fresh petition in regard
